articles.title: Islam vs Usman: This Is the Fight
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChael 170 pounds is murderers‚Äô row, and that‚Äôs exactly why Islam Makhachev needs Kamaru Usman. Not just for a payday, not just for a name ‚Äì for legacy. Chael breaks down the current state of the UFC welterweight division, from killers like Michael Morales, Sean Brady, Ian Garry, Belal Muhammad, and Shavkat Rakhmonov, to what really makes sense next for Islam. On paper, you can argue a lot of contenders‚Ä¶ but when you factor in history, greatness, and what actually moves the needle, one name keeps coming back: Kamaru Usman. Chael explains why giving Usman a title shot isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúrewarding‚Äù him for a dominant career ‚Äì it might actually be the best thing you can do for Islam. If Makhachev goes out and does to Usman what even Khamzat Chimaev couldn‚Äôt, that changes the GOAT and pound-for-pound conversations overnight. We also get into Georges St-Pierre, Khabib Nurmagomedov, and how Islam‚Äôs resume will age as guys like Arman Tsarukyan rise to the top. This is a cold sport, and matchmaking at this level is about more than rankings. It‚Äôs about legacy, star power, and who you beat when it matters. articles.title: Trump Claims White House Card's Only Title Fights
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChaelBad President Donald Trump just dropped a bombshell about the rumored UFC White House card ‚Äì and whether he nailed every detail or not, the theme of what he said is wild. He floated June 14th, talked about nine title fights, and even used the phrase ‚Äúonly title fights.‚Äù Now, maybe one of those details is off‚Ä¶ but if even one of them is right, everything changes. Chael breaks down what an all-title-fight card (or even an all-title-fight main card) would really mean. If it‚Äôs ‚Äúonly title fights,‚Äù where does that leave all the rumors we‚Äôve heard about Conor McGregor, Jon Jones vs. Alex Pereira, and the heavyweight picture around Tom Aspinall and Ciryl Gane? Chael walks through how you could still make Conor a title fight with Max Holloway‚Äôs BMF belt, how Jones‚ÄìPereira could slide into a championship scenario, and what happens if Aspinall stays on the shelf long enough to force an interim or undisputed shake-up. This isn‚Äôt just fantasy matchmaking; it‚Äôs trying to read between the lines of what the host of the event is saying. If Trump is talking nine title fights and ‚Äúonly title fights,‚Äù even if the numbers are fuzzy, the direction is clear: the UFC is aiming for something historically stacked. Where does this all land? We‚Äôll see. But it sure sounds like we‚Äôre in for a night loaded with gold. articles.title: Should Ilia Topuria Lose His Belt?
articles.description: Get 15% OFF The House of Atlas Razor Kit + Before and After Set with the code CHAEL at https://www.houseofatlas.com/CHAEL! #houseofatlaspod Should Ilia Topuria still be the champion? That‚Äôs the question circling the UFC offices right now, and it‚Äôs a lot colder ‚Äî and a lot more complicated ‚Äî than fans realize. I just walked out of the UFC Performance Institute in Las Vegas, and everybody has an opinion on Ilia Topuria. Some say he‚Äôs the best boxer in MMA, others say he‚Äôs the future face of the sport, maybe even headlining the White House card. But for the first time, a very respected voice hit me with a different argument entirely: Ilia should have been stripped. Not sidelined. Not given grace. Stripped. This person walked me through the history of the interim title ‚Äî why it exists, when it‚Äôs used, and why illness or injury has always been the deciding factor. They brought up Dominick Cruz‚Äôs three-and-a-half-year layoff, ACL after ACL, and the compassion that kept him champion. Their claim? Ilia‚Äôs situation doesn‚Äôt fall under illness or injury‚Ä¶ so why keep the belt? Now, I don‚Äôt agree. I believe Ilia Topuria has handled a tough situation with transparency and courage. He even told the UFC to move on without him if needed ‚Äî a man‚Äôs move. But the question remains: Should a champion keep his title if he refuses to fight and it‚Äôs not due to injury? This is the cold side of a cold sport. And it‚Äôs worth discussing. articles.title: Why Chael's Picking Joshua Van for Fighter of the Year
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChael Fighter of the Year isn‚Äôt a statistic. It‚Äôs an argument and Chael Sonnen isn‚Äôt afraid to make it. In this clip, Chael breaks down why he believes Joshua Van deserves serious consideration in the Fighter of the Year conversation ‚Äî even while others point to Merab Dvalishvili‚Äôs year of title fights as the obvious pick. This isn‚Äôt a takedown of anyone. It‚Äôs a challenge to the way fans think about greatness. Chael compares championship moments, calendar-year performance, and consistency ‚Äî explaining why ‚Äúperfect‚Äù isn‚Äôt required to be dominant. Drawing from past debates and controversial picks, he shows how momentum, difficulty of opposition, and big moments matter just as much as undefeated records. The conversation also turns toward today‚Äôs hot topic: rematches. Chael explains why one future fight could completely change how the past is remembered ‚Äî and why fans should be careful about rushing to judgment when careers are still being written. Whether you agree or disagree, this breakdown makes one thing clear: this isn‚Äôt about popularity. It‚Äôs about performance. If you love real fight debate, not clickbait, not hype but hard opinions backed by logic, this one is for you. articles.title: The ONLY solution to stopping eye pokes in the UFC... #ufc
articles.description: Bare-knuckle wrestling is intense, but Chael Sonnen argues that blaming the gloves is a massive copout. In this clip, he explains why fighters must be held accountable for actions like eye pokes, grabbing the fence, or kicking opponents while down ‚Äî regardless of whether gloves are involved. Chael points out that referees and fans often label these incidents ‚Äúunintentional,‚Äù but that mindset ignores responsibility. Even without gloves, fighters can and should avoid fouls. The real issue isn‚Äôt the equipment ‚Äî it‚Äôs accountability. If someone pokes an opponent in the eye, someone is at fault, plain and simple. This clip is essential for anyone following MMA rules, bare-knuckle combat, or fighter safety. Chael‚Äôs analysis highlights how leniency for ‚Äúaccidents‚Äù undermines fairness, sets poor precedents, and affects how fights are judged. He stresses that proper enforcement and accountability maintain the integrity of the sport, rather than blaming gloves or equipment. For fans of MMA, bare-knuckle fighting, fighter safety, and insider fight analysis, this breakdown delivers Chael Sonnen‚Äôs sharp and unfiltered perspective.

articles.title: Merab Dvalishvili vs Petr Yan: Here‚Äôs What Happened
articles.description: Get 15% OFF The House of Atlas Razor Kit + Before and After Set with the code CHAEL at https://www.houseofatlas.com/CHAEL! #houseofatlaspod Something felt wrong before this fight ever started ‚Äî and Petr Yan proved exactly why. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why the odds made no sense, why Petr Yan was being dismissed far too easily, and why Merab Dvalishvili was walking into something much more dangerous than he expected. This wasn‚Äôt a wrestling match. This wasn‚Äôt a kickboxing match. This was mixed martial arts ‚Äî and Yan fought it that way. Chael walks through what mattered: defensive underhooks, walking Merab down, the discipline of jabs and crosses, the lack of wasted motion, and the threat of wrestling that made every punch more dangerous. Yan didn‚Äôt throw everything. He committed to what worked. The conversation also breaks down the myth of ‚Äúbetter striker vs better wrestler‚Äù and why that thinking gets fighters beat at the highest level. When championship fights happen, we don‚Äôt find out who‚Äôs the better grappler or striker ‚Äî we find out who‚Äôs the better mixed martial artist. Merab fought like a champion. But Petr Yan fought like the man who had the answer. This wasn‚Äôt chaos. This was control. Only one kind of fighting wins at the top level‚Ä¶ and Petr Yan just demonstrated it. articles.title: Joe Rogan wants Gable Steveson in the UFC #ufc
articles.description: Joe Rogan says it best: Gable Steveson is an absolute nightmare for anyone in the UFC. In this clip, Chael Sonnen breaks down how the UFC could handle one of the most explosive young talents in MMA. Rogan even clipped Steveson‚Äôs last fight and sent it directly to Dana White ‚Äî a signal that this is a fighter you don‚Äôt ignore. Chael lays out the dilemma: Contender Series signings are one thing, but how do you introduce a fighter of Steveson‚Äôs caliber without wasting his talent or throwing him into an undercard he doesn‚Äôt belong on? Chael suggests a strategic approach: pay Steveson his worth, build him carefully, and consider a high-profile fight in another promotion like the PFL to gauge his readiness against elite opponents such as Francis Ngannou. If he wins, you‚Äôve got a star ready for the big stage; if he doesn‚Äôt, you have your answer without risking your top talent. This clip is a must-watch for fans of Gable Steveson, Contender Series prospects, and UFC matchmaking strategies. Chael‚Äôs insights show the balance between building a fighter‚Äôs career, protecting the UFC‚Äôs investment, and keeping fans hyped.

articles.title: Henry Cejudo‚Äôs Last Stand
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChael This wasn‚Äôt about rankings. This wasn‚Äôt about money. This wasn‚Äôt even about winning. This was about showing up when you already know it‚Äôs over. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why Henry Cejudo‚Äôs final fight mattered more than any belt he ever wore. When a fighter steps into the cage knowing there‚Äôs no return, something changes. Every shot hurts more. Every exchange costs more. And the only question left is simple: How bad do you want it? Chael walks through what happens psychologically when an athlete knows this is truly their last night ‚Äî why most fighters freeze, why some collapse, and why very few rise. With a busted nose, a swollen eye, and the score slipping away, Henry never checked out. He leaned in. Then comes the bigger truth. The day of the pure wrestler is gone. This breakdown also exposes how the sport itself has evolved ‚Äî from specialists to complete fighters. Wrestling alone no longer wins championships. Striking alone doesn‚Äôt either. The new era demands everything, all at once‚Ä¶ and shows no mercy. Henry Cejudo didn‚Äôt quit. The sport simply moved forward. And this night proved it. articles.title: Tom Aspinall is owed an apology‚Ä¶ #ufc

In this video, Chael asks a simple question: do some fans owe Tom Aspinall an apology? Because the heavyweight champ wasn‚Äôt just shaken up‚Ä¶ he was legitimately hurt, and the situation could have cost him his belt over one wrong word. Chael breaks down the moment that sparked all the controversy: three eye pokes in under three minutes. That‚Äôs nearly one-third of the available fingers finding their way directly into Tom‚Äôs eye. Fans love to act like real fighters ‚Äúwould have continued,‚Äù but Chael explains why that mindset ignores the rules entirely. If Tom was hurt ‚Äî and he clearly was ‚Äî why wasn‚Äôt it a disqualification? Why do we always rush to call it ‚Äúaccidental‚Äù instead of acknowledging how egregious it actually was? This clip digs into fighter safety, the difference between accidental and reckless fouls, and the razor-thin line Tom walked as a champion. One wrong phrase to the referee and he could have lost his belt in a no-contest or forced stoppage. If you care about fairness, fighter protection, and the truth behind what really happened in the Octagon, this is essential Chael Sonnen analysis. Watch more breakdowns on UFC heavyweights, title implications, and controversial moments right here.

articles.title: Islam Makhachev vs Ilia Topuria is becoming uninteresting #ufc
articles.description: Ilia Topuria and Islam Makhachev finally had a real reason to fight‚Äîyet somehow, the matchup has drifted even further apart. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains how Ilia managed to lose his ranking without ever losing a fight, and why that shift changes everything. Chael lays out the situation clearly: Ilia didn‚Äôt get beat, didn‚Äôt take damage, didn‚Äôt even stumble‚Ä¶ yet he slips in the rankings and suddenly Islam has new directions to go. Instead of the long-hyped Ilia vs Islam showdown, the division now has fresh contenders. Islam Makhachev could be staring at a matchup with Kamaru Usman, a stylistic puzzle we‚Äôre not convinced Islam can solve. Meanwhile, Ilia Topuria may be heading toward Arman Tsarukyan, and fans aren‚Äôt confident Ilia gets over on a surging, dangerous Arman, either. The result? The fight everyone‚Äôs been circling for months has lost steam, lost urgency, and‚Äîaccording to Chael‚Äîlost its intrigue. The motivations are gone, the rankings have shifted, and both men now have bigger problems directly in front of them. If you‚Äôre following the chaos at lightweight and featherweight, or you want Chael‚Äôs unfiltered view on Islam Makhachev, Ilia Topuria, Kamaru Usman, and Arman Tsarukyan, this is the clip to watch. Watch more analysis right here.

articles.title: Alex Pereira calls Jake Paul for a boxing match... #ufc
articles.description: When you call out Jake Paul, timing matters‚Äîand this fighter picked the worst possible moment. Chael Sonnen breaks down why this move doesn‚Äôt just miss the mark‚Ä¶ it actively damages the guy‚Äôs brand. In this clip, Chael reacts to a fighter openly flirting with a boxing match against Jake Paul while Jake is on the verge of facing Anthony Joshua. Instead of building momentum, he undercuts himself by suggesting the matchup would be ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù or ‚Äúcompetitive‚Äù right before Jake steps into the biggest risk of his career. Chael lays out exactly why this is a disastrous strategy: you‚Äôre calling out a guy you can‚Äôt secure a contract with, who might get stopped by Joshua, and you‚Äôve already told the public he‚Äôs on your level. The moment Jake loses, you lose your selling point. This is classic Chael‚Äîsharp, analytical, and brutally honest. He explains how timing, optics, and public perception make or break a potential boxing crossover. If you want a fight with a star, you don‚Äôt attach yourself to them right before a likely loss. You wait, position yourself, and elevate your own value. If you enjoy straight-talk breakdowns on Jake Paul, Anthony Joshua, boxing politics, and combat-sports marketing, this clip delivers. Watch the full segment and check out more Chael analysis right here.
